newsitem.title: PAKISTAN: Nine killed in Pakistan sectarian shooting.
newsitem.headline: Nine killed in Pakistan sectarian shooting.

text.p: Gunmen riding a motorcycle sprayed bullets on a busy market in Pakistan's central province of Punjab on Thursday, killing nine people and wounding three, doctors and police said.

A police official said three gunmen riding on a single motorcycle targeted shopkeepers in the Faisal Bazaar and Rahim Market in the small town, 100 km (60 miles) southwest of southern Punjab's main city of Multan.
"The masked gunmen then drove away from the scene," Mohammad Aslam of the Khairpur Tameywala Police Station told Reuters. He said the incident appeared to be sectarian violence.
A doctor at the town's Civil Hospital said nine people were killed and three wounded.
Muhammad Younis Suhail said six of the dead belonged to the minority Shi'ite Moslem sect and three from the majority Sunni Moslem sect. "Most of the killed are shopkeepers."
There was no immediate information about the identity of the gunmen.
The incident follows a series of similar attacks on Shi'ites and Sunnis. Militants of the two sects have blamed each other for the attacks.
Shi'ite Moslems have recently been the target of attacks in Pakistan, particularly in southern Punjab.
A Shi'ite doctor was killed in Lodhran, 75 km (45 miles) from Multan by masked gunmen on April 15
A long running feud between the two sects cost more than 170 lives in Pakistan last year.
Sunnis dominate Pakistan's population of more than 130 million, while Shi'ites represent about 15 percent but are in majority in neighbouring Iran.
